block.p: I read the article "Preserving the Legacy of Modernist Design" [April 7] and was perplexed that the article, while mentioning single-glazed windows and higher operating costs, did not equate these items to greater consumption of fuel, which is a major component of the greenhouse effect. Buildings use 40 percent of the world's fossil fuel reserves. Renovating these buildings with the latest technology in windows and insulation could cut that usage in half, reducing the greenhouse effect and saving resources for future generations.

I read the article "Preserving the Legacy of Modernist Design" [April 7] and was perplexed that the article, while mentioning single-glazed windows and higher operating costs, did not equate these items to greater consumption of fuel, which is a major component of the greenhouse effect. Buildings use 40 percent of the world's fossil fuel reserves. Renovating these buildings with the latest technology in windows and insulation could cut that usage in half, reducing the greenhouse effect and saving resources for future generations.

In addition, the article did not mention at all that most of these buildings have inoperable windows and undersized and antiquated ventilation systems, leading to poor indoor air quality and a reduction in worker productivity. Let's stop worrying so much about preserving glass and steel and start worrying about worker health and reducing harmful emissions.
BARRY H. DIMSON President, Healthy Properties
Healthy Properties is a Manhattan company dedicated to promoting and implementing green building practices in the real estate industry.
